questions.text: Which of the following statements about the administration of anti D is correct ?
questions.solution:
Routine antenatal anti D prophylaxis is usually not administered until 28 weeks' gestation, since transplacental haemorrhages large enough to cause sensitisation do not usually occur until the third trimester and thus Rhesus antibodies usually develop after the 28th week of gestation.

If the baby's blood group is RhD negative no further action is required. If the baby's blood group is RhD positive, Anti D will be required for baby's mother. Administer intramuscular RhD Immunoglobulin (Anti D) to the woman with informed consent (within 48 72 hours of birth).

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 156.

questions.text: A 27 yr old female at 9wk POG, with vaginal bleeding. She advices she has terrible morning sickness. Examination reveals a 14wk size uterus. Blood and pelvic ultrasound are shows numerous anechoic spaces What is the idea treatment of choice in this situation ?
questions.solution:
Given sonography picture is suggestive of molar pregnancy.

A molar pregnancy can't be allowed to continue. To prevent complications, the affected placental tissue must be removed. Treatment usually consists of one or more of the following steps: Dilation and curettage (D&C)

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 256.

questions.text: A 32 yr old female attends for induction of labor at 41wk. She had membrane sweep at 40week. She is examined and cervix is found to be 1cm dilated and 2cm long and fetal head is engaged. What would be the preferred method of induction of labour?
questions.solution:
Cervical ripening is the process of softening and widening the cervix in preparation for childbirth . People who need labor induction are the most likely to need cervical ripening.

Pharmacologic agents available for cervical ripening and labor induction include prostaglandins, misoprostol, mifepristone, and relaxin. When the Bishop score is favorable, the preferred pharmacologic agent is oxytocin.

Dinoprostone (PGE2) gel is most commonly used.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 178.

questions.text: Most common cause of acute kidney injury in pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Hyperemesis gravidarum is a common cause of pregnancy-related AKI during the first trimester.

Hyperemesis gravidarum refers to intractable vomiting during pregnancy, leading to weight loss and volume depletion, resulting in ketonuria and/or ketonemia.

There is no consensus on specific diagnostic criteria, but it generally refers to the severe end of the spectrum regarding nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 278.

questions.text: 34 years old lady using OCP since 5 months presents with amenorrhea since 6 weeks. Which of the following is best to calculate gestational age in this case?
questions.solution:
• First Trimester Dating: Sonographic assessment within the first 13 weeks and 6 days will provide the most accurate estimate of gestational age.
  • Both transvaginal and transabdominal approaches may be used.
  • However, the transvaginal approach may provide a more clear and accurate view of early embryonic structures.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 278.

questions.text: The major contribution of the amniotic fluid after 20 weeks of gestation
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid initially originates from maternal plasma, but by the second half of pregnancy, fetal urination and swallowing contribute significantly to the volume of amniotic fluid.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 78.

questions.solution:
For emergency treatment in preeclampsia, IV hydralazine, labetalol and oral nifedipine can be used.

questions.text: Placenta previa will show
questions.solution:
• Most of the time, placenta previa has no symptoms; it is often found during a routine ultrasound test.
  • For those who do have symptoms, the most common is painless bleeding from the vagina during the second half of pregnancy.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 258.

questions.text: A 30 yr old female is 16week pregnant in her 3rd pregnancy. Her BP- 155/105mmhg 2 week back and her BP in current visit is 150/100mmhg. Her urine analysis shows no proteins, Creatinine- 1.3mg/dl, SGOT- 70. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Superimposed preeclampsia refers to women with chronic arterial hypertension (primary or secondary) who develop preeclampsia (PE).

Term applies after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 358.

questions.text: Banana sign in pregnancy is characteristically seen-
questions.solution:
Certain fetal cranial abnormalities found on second-trimester sonograms can be signs of an open spina bifida. In particular, an abnormal configuration of the cerebellum, known as the banana sign, has been associated with neural tube defects.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 435.

questions.text: Patient with recurrent abortion diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What will be the treatment?
questions.solution:
• The prognosis of a subsequent pregnancy in women with APLAs is good. Although this was not a randomized clinical trial, combined treatment of aspirin and heparin seemed associated with a better outcome in women with APLAs, but not in women with unexplained recurrent miscarriage.
  • If blood tests show you have abnormal antiphospholipid antibodies, but you don't have a history of blood clots, lowdose aspirin tablets are usually recommended.
  • Women with recurrent miscarriage should be offered referral to a specialist clinic. Pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome should be considered for treatment with low-dose aspirin plus heparin to prevent further miscarriage.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 4th/ed, pg no 467.

questions.text: 32yr, primigravida presents at 33wk, with abdominal pain and Preterm labour. Which among the following is the appropriate management for her?
questions.solution:
• Antenatal magnesium sulphate administration should be considered for fetal neuroprotection when women present at ≤33 + 6 weeks with imminent preterm birth, defined as a high likelihood of birth because of active labour.(WHO guidlines)

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 4th/ed, pg no 267.

choices.text: Lift the head to relieve pressure on cord
Expedite delivery after confirming the FHR status

questions.text: After ARM has been done, there is sudden deceleration of fetal heart rate and cord was seen coming through vagina. Which of the following should not done in management ?
questions.solution:
• Principles of management of umbilical cord prolapse
  • Call for help.
  • Continuous fetal monitoring.
  • O2 by face mask.
  • Immediate delivery.
  • Essentially by CS - allow instrumental/vaginal delivery if deemed quicker.
  • Funic decompression/elevation of the presenting part.
  • Funic reduction (rarely used)
  • Tocolysis.
  • Keep the cord moist.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 278.

questions.text: Female at 37wk with mild labour pain persistently 1cm dilated but not effaced. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Prolonged latent phase labor may result in physical and emotional exhaustion of the mother. Education, support, hydration, position changes, and other non-pharmacologic measures such as massage or water immersion should be first line treatments if maternal and fetal evaluation is reassuring.

Approximately 10% of women with a prolonged latent phase are actually in false labor, and their contractions eventually abate spontaneously. The management of a prolonged latent phase involves either augmenting uterine activity with oxytocin or providing a sedative-induced period of maternal rest.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 4th/ed, pg no 167.

questions.text: Early pregnancy sign involving Asymmetrical enlargement of uterus due to lateral implanation of blastocyst-
questions.solution:
• Piskacek's sign is a physical indication of pregnancy. It is defined as asymmetry of the enlarged uterus, palpable during pelvic examination, after the first few weeks of pregnancy.
  • It is attributed to lateral implantation of the embryo, which can enlarge one uterine horn before the other.
  • Palmer's sign: uterine contractions felt during bimanual examination.
  • Hegar's sign: during bimanual examination, the two fingers in the anterior fornix can be approximated to fingers of the abdominal hand behind the uterus due to softening of the lower part of the uterus and its emptiness.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 4th/ed, pg no 67.

questions.text: What is the dose drugs used for MTP at 6week
questions.solution:
MIFEPRISTONE:

For oral dosage form (tablets):For termination of pregnancy (70 days or less) taken together with misoprostol:

  • Adults-200 milligrams (mg) as a single dose on Day 1. This is followed 2 days later by 800 micrograms (mcg) (four-200 mcg tablets) of misoprostol as a single dose

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with 36 w+6 days gestation. On examination, fetal was transverse lie with adequate liquor, placenta in normal position. Weight of the baby is 2.8 kg. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
ECV may be indicated when the fetus is breech or in an oblique or transverse lie after 37 0/7 weeks gestation. [3] The overall success rate for ECV approaches 60%, is cost-effective, and can lead to decreased cesarean delivery rates.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 423.

questions.text: A 22-year-old comes to OPD she is primigravida 20 weeks POG, on examination fundal height comes 16 weeks size. USG showed reduced liquor. Probable cause
questions.solution:
Symptoms and Causes

  • Congenital anomalies that affect your baby's kidneys or urinary tract.
  • Problems with your placenta.
  • Going more than two weeks past your due date.
  • Hypertension or preeclampsia.
  • Diabetes.
  • Dehydration.
  • Prelabor rupture of the membranes.
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • In the early weeks of pregnancy, the amniotic fluid is mostly water that comes from your body.
  • After about 20 weeks of pregnancy, your baby's urine makes up most of the fluid.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 23.

questions.text: Which complication is specific to monochorionic twins?
questions.solution:
Problems that can affect the health of monochorionic twins include:

  • Birth weight differences.
  • Amniotic fluid problems.
  • Umbilical cord entanglement or compression.
  • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Twin reversed arterial perfusion sequence (TRAP sequence)
  • Increased risk of birth defects in each twin.

Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 223.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a teratogenic drug ?
questions.solution: Reference: D.C Dutta's textbook of obsgtetrics, 10th/ed pg no 423.
